ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned to write for a general audience and to incorporate more complex / risky writing tools (humor, poetically long sentences, open-ended conclusions) into my work. I also learned to persist in the face of adversity and to seek out / consider more feedback from others.

In this course I learned about different writing techniques to make my writing more succinct. Further, we read medical pieces in several forms and learned how to write opinion pieces, patient profiles, and long form research papers. I learned how to incorporate style and mimic the style of others.
I learned how to interview patients and professional writers. I also developed skills with writing journalistic medical and scientific pieces.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Professor Epstein is a wonderful person and it is a privilege to take classes with her, one that any student interested in medicine or writing should consider. She arranges an abundance of opportunities to chat and learn from experts in the field and patients with the conditions you read about. She encourages taking risks in your writing, which I believe everyone should experiment with. With luck, you will also be able to meet a wonderful group of fellow students as I did. 

Weaknesses: None relating to the course. I must admit that writing is not one of my strengths, which made the class very challenging. But that is less an issue of the class and more my personal interests.

Strengths:
- Professor Epstein is always available to help and loves to connect and work with her students.
- Learned about how to trim down essays and where to cut out unnecessary words.
- Had helpful workshop periods to get feedback and read other peoples work
- Engaging readings
Weaknesses:
- Not too many that I can think of. Potentially would like longer periods of time to workshop.
- Class sometimes went over which is difficult if you have a commitment or class that starts 10 minutes later.

Strengths: Excellent readings, lots of opportunities to talk to well-known, accomplished medical journalists and writers, great feedback on writing, and the chance to take a small seminar with Prof. Epstein, who is passionate about teaching and really knows what she's talking about.

Weaknesses: None that I can think of.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would highly recommend this course to any student interested in writing, medicine, or public health. At the same time, it is a serious time investment. If you are not highly talented / passionate about writing, I would say it is a comparable time investment to CPSC323 (systems) or CHEM332 (physical chemistry).

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to people. If you are interested in the medical field this is the perfect course to take because you learn about new things in the medical field and improve on your writing. The work load is manageable and Professor Epstein is a brilliant professor.

Yes, I would strongly recommend this class to anyone interested in a) journalism or writing and b) medicine or science. You will learn so much. Of my classes this semester, this class was hands-down my favorite.
